evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: In March 2025, President Trump issued another such executive order, determining that certain agencies and subdivisions have “as a primary function intelligence, counterintelligence, investigative, or national security work” and that the labor‑relations provisions of the FSLMRS and FSA “cannot be applied to those agencies and agency subdivisions in a manner consistent with national security requirements and considerations.”  Exec. Order No. 14,251, §§ 1-3, 90 Fed. Reg. 14,553, 14,553-14,555 (Apr. 3, 2025).

extracted.value: In March 2025, President Trump issued Executive Order No. 14,251 titled “Exclusions from Federal Labor-Management Relations Programs.”

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: The executive order designates all subdivisions of the State Department and USAID employing members of the Foreign Service. Id. § 3, 90 Fed. Reg. at 14,555.

extracted.value: The executive order designates all subdivisions of the State Department and USAID employing members of the Foreign Service.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: The same day, the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) issued guidance to federal agencies regarding the executive order. Ezell, Guidance on Executive Order (Mar. 27, 2025), https://perma.cc/QH4A-MQ9F (OPM Guidance).  OPM explained that “covered agencies and subdivisions are no longer subject to the collective‑bargaining requirements” of the FSLMRS and FSA and “are no longer required to collectively bargain with Federal unions.”

extracted.value: The Office of Personnel Management issued guidance on the same day affirming that covered agencies are no longer subject to collective‑bargaining requirements.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: Prior to the issuance of the executive order, plaintiff AFSA was certified as the exclusive representative of all members of the Foreign Service.

extracted.value: AFSA was certified as the exclusive representative of all Foreign Service employees before the executive order.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: Shortly after the executive order was issued, the State Department terminated its collective‑bargaining agreement with AFSA.

extracted.value: The State Department terminated its collective‑bargaining agreement with AFSA shortly after the executive order was issued.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: Several other designated agencies (with employees in the civil service) filed suits requesting declaratory judgments that, in light of Executive Order 14,251, they are legally entitled to rescind such agreements.

extracted.value: Other designated agencies filed suits seeking declaratory judgments to rescind their collective‑bargaining agreements in light of Executive Order 14,251.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: Plaintiff moved for a preliminary injunction, which the court granted on May 14. Dkt. 36.

extracted.value: The district court granted a preliminary injunction to AFSA on May 14, 2025.

evidence.source_document: Emergency Motion for an Immediate Administrative Stay and Stay Pending Appeal
evidence.text: The court also held that AFSA faced irreparable harm from loss of bargaining power and union dues. Op. 29-33.

extracted.value: The court held that AFSA faced irreparable harm from loss of bargaining power and union dues.
